para.text: "Demand management strategies" means measures used to control and reduce the demand for existing and new parking facilities.

para.heading: Develop.
para.text: "Develop", when used in connection with a parking project, means to plan, design, construct, improve, expand, renovate, rehabilitate, equip, furnish, or convert property to create a parking project, either directly by the Authority or through the use of other persons.

para.heading: Enabling Act.
para.text: "Enabling Act" means the State Parking Authorities Act, codified at Article 41, Title 14, Subtitle 3 of the Maryland Code, as amended from time to time.

para.heading: Operate.
para.text: "Operate", when used in connection with a parking project, means to maintain, manage, repair, improve, expand, alter, modify, regulate, or otherwise control the operation of the parking project, either directly by the Authority or through the use of other persons.

para.heading: Parking Project.
para.text: "Parking Project" means all or part of any property in the City that the Authority is authorized to acquire, develop, or operate under the Enabling Act and this subtitle.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: "Person" has the meaning stated in § 1-107(a) {"Person: In general"} of the City Code's General Provisions Article.

para.heading: Inclusion of governmental entities.
para.text: Notwithstanding § 1-107(b) {"Person: Exclusion"} of the General Provisions Article, in this subtitle "person"also includes a governmental entity or an instrumentality or unit of a governmental entity.

para.heading: Property.
para.text: "Property" includes:
any real or personal property, tangible or intangible; and
any interest in real or personal property, including any franchise, license, or easement.

para.heading: Public Bonds.
para.text: "Public Bonds" means any borrowing evidenced by the issuance of bonds, notes, certificates, or other instruments that are sold or structured for sale to retail purchasers of municipal or public obligations and that are typically accompanied by the preparation of a prospectus, offering statement, or similar disclosure document.

section.heading: Construction.
section.text: This subtitle and the powers granted under it must be broadly interpreted to allow the Authority to achieve the purposes of:

para.text: the Enabling Act; and
this subtitle.

para.heading: Authority established.
para.text: There is a Baltimore City Parking Authority, established under the Enabling Act as a body corporate and politic.

para.heading: Corporate powers.
para.text: The Authority may:
sue and be sued; and
adopt, use, and alter at will a corporate seal.

para.heading: Purposes.
para.text: The Authority is created for the purposes set forth in the Enabling Act.

The Authority may exercise any of the following powers, either singly or in any combination, in each instance to the extent the Board determines is necessary or convenient to achieve the purposes of the Authority.
The powers enumerated in this section are in addition to any other powers or authorizations specifically granted to the Authority by law.

para.heading: Acquisition of property.
para.text: The Authority may acquire property:
to develop parking projects; or
otherwise as necessary or desirable for carrying out its purposes.

para.heading: Acquisition of projects.
para.text: The Authority may acquire already-existing parking projects.

para.heading: Funding, development, or construction of projects.

para.text: The Authority may fund, develop, or construct parking projects.
The final design of any parking structure that the Authority funds, develops, or constructs is subject to the approval of the Planning Commission.

para.heading: Operation of projects.
para.text: The Authority may operate the parking projects that it acquires or develops.

para.heading: Use of projects.
para.text: The Authority may:
contract with any person for the use, by persons other than the Authority, of all or part of any parking project; and
subject to the approval of the Board of Estimates, set the rates, tolls, rents, fees, charges, or other financial or non-financial impositions for any parking project.

para.heading: Disposition of property.
para.text: To the extent permitted by the Enabling Act, the Authority may sell or otherwise transfer to the City or other persons its interest in any property or parking project.
The Authority may enter into contracts necessary or convenient to the exercise of its powers.
The Authority's contracts are not subject to Article VI, § 11 of the City Charter.
However, any contract involving an expenditure of $25,000 or more is subject to the approval of the Board of Estimates.

para.heading: Research and studies.
para.text: The Authority may:
conduct research and studies relating to parking and demand management strategies, including the preparation of short-term or long-terms plans; and
contract with persons to assist in these studies and plans.

para.heading: Grants.
para.text: The Authority may accept grants from any governmental entity, including the State and the City, or any political subdivision of the State, and from any other person.

para.heading: Bylaws.
para.text: The Authority may adopt bylaws for the management and regulation of its affairs.
Subject to the approval of the Board of Estimates, the Authority may adopt rules and regulations governing the operation and use of its parking projects.
A copy of all rules and regulations must be filed with the Department of Legislative Reference before they take effect.

para.heading: General.
para.text: The Authority may do all other acts and things necessary or convenient to carry out the powers granted by this subtitle or by any other law.

para.heading: Exemptions.
para.text: To the extent not specifically made subject to laws and procedures that otherwise apply to units of the City government, the Authority is exempt from those laws and procedures.

para.heading: Scope.
para.text: The functions authorized by this section may be exercised as necessary or appropriate to improve efficiency and maximize revenues, subject, however, to the limitations of applicable State and local laws and existing contractual obligations of the City.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Subject to the limitations specified in subsection (a) of this section, the City and the Authority may contract for the Authority's undertaking any 1 or more of the following functions:
operation of 1 or more parking projects owned or controlled by the City;
installation and maintenance of City parking meters;
enforcement of City parking ordinances and regulations; and
otherwise managing part or all of the City's parking operations.

para.heading: Management and operations plan and report.

para.text: At least 45 days before it assumes any new function or any new part of a function under this section, the Authority must submit a written management and operations plan to the City Council and the Board of Estimates.

As long as the Authority is performing any function under this section, the Authority must submit an annual written report to the City Council and the Board of Estimates on its management and operations under this section.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The Authority is not an agency of the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore, and its officers and employees are not agents or employees of the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore.

para.heading: In particular.
para.text: The Authority:
may not pledge the full faith and credit of the City or otherwise obligate the City to any borrowing or contract;
does not have any taxing authority;
may not exercise the power of eminent domain; and
may not issue any public bonds.

para.heading: City to be held harmless.
para.text: The Authority must indemnify and hold harmless the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore and its officers, agents, and employees against all acts, conditions, damages, suits, claims, and liabilities arising out of or in connection with any activities of the Authority or of its Board, Executive Director, officers, agents, or employees.
The powers of the Authority are exercised by a Board of Directors.
The Board consists of 5 members, of which:
4 are appointed by the Mayor and confirmed by the City Council; and
1 is a member of the City Council appointed by the City Council President.
Each member of the Board must be:
a resident of Baltimore City; and
a person of ability, experience, and integrity.
At least 1 member of the Board must have mass transit involvement.
The term of a member is 3 years.
The terms of the members are staggered as required by the terms provided for the members first appointed to the Board.
At the end of a term, a member continues to serve until his or her successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until his or her successor is appointed and qualifies.
Members may be appointed to succeed themselves. However, a member may not serve more than 2 consecutive full terms.

para.heading: Removal.
para.text: The Mayor or City Council President, as the case may be, may remove at will any member of the Board appointed by him or her.

para.heading: Compensation; expenses.
para.text: The members of the Board:
serve without compensation; but
are entitled to reimbursement for reasonable expenses incurred in the performance of their duties, as provided in the Board's rules governing expenses.

section.heading: Board of Directors — Officers; staff; delegation.

para.text: The Mayor designates the Chair of the Board.
From among its members, the Board must select a treasurer, a secretary, and any other officers that the Board determines.
The Board must select an executive director, as provided in § 13-10 of this subtitle.
The Board may:
employ attorneys, accountants, technical experts, agents, and employees, permanent or temporary, as the Board requires;
determine their qualifications and duties; and
fix their compensation.

para.heading: Delegation.
para.text: The Board may delegate to one or more of its agents or employees any of the Board's powers that the Board considers necessary to carry out this subtitle.

para.heading: No personal liability.
para.text: No member of the Board may be held personally liable for the obligations of the Authority, and the rights of creditors may be exercised solely against the Authority.

section.heading: Board of Directors — Quorum; open meetings; public records.

para.heading: Quorum.
para.text: Three members of the Board constitute a quorum.

para.heading: Open meetings.
para.text: All meetings of the Board must be conducted in accordance with the State Open Meetings Act, Title 3 of the State General Provisions Article.

para.heading: Public records.
para.text: All records of the Authority must be open to public inspection in accordance with the State Public Information Act, Title 4 of the State General Provisions Article.

para.heading: Chief Administrative Officer.
para.text: The Executive Director is the chief administrative officer of the Authority.
The Executive Director may not be a member of the Board.
The Executive Director serves at the pleasure of the Board.
Any employment contract with the Executive Director may not exceed 3 years, but may be renewed up to 3 years at a time by agreement between the Board and the Executive Director.

para.heading: Duties.
para.text: In addition to any other rights, powers, and duties granted by the Board, the Executive Director:
supervises and manages the day-to-day operations of the Authority and its employees and contractors;
prepares the Authority's various plans and reports for review and approval by the Board;
implements the approved financial plan and arranges for the collection, deposit, and disbursement of all charges and revenues of the Authority; and
establishes the procedures and processes needed to perform the functions called for under the financial plan.

para.heading: Fiscal year.
para.text: The Authority's fiscal year is the same as the City's fiscal year.
Annually, the Board of Directors must develop and, subject to the approval of the Board of Estimates, adopt a financial plan for the ensuing fiscal year.
The financial plan for each fiscal year:
must contain the Authority's proposed plan for both operations and capital expenditures in that fiscal year; and
may include a narrative of initiatives to be undertaken by the Authority in its effort to develop parking projects and demand management strategies.

para.heading: Submission of proposed plan to Board of Estimates.
para.text: At least 2 months before the start of a new fiscal year, the Board of Directors must submit its proposed financial plan and all background material to the Board of Estimates for its review and approval.

para.heading: Annual report.
para.text: Within 6 months after the end of each fiscal year, the Authority must publish and make available to the public an annual report that summarizes, in a non-technical, readable format:
the Authority's activities during the preceding fiscal year;
the Authority's future plans ; and
the Authority's consideration and use of demand management strategies and the effectiveness of those strategies in reducing the need for new parking.

section.heading: Deposit of funds; audits and examinations; financial statement.

para.heading: Deposits.
para.text: The Authority's treasurer must deposit and invest all moneys received by the Authority in one or more financial institutions, consistent with the requirements of State Code Article 95, § 22F {"Local government investment guidelines"}.
The Authority must:
maintain adequate books and records; and
within 90 days after the end of each fiscal year, prepare audited financial statements in accordance with generally accepted governmental accounting principles.
A copy of the audited financial statements must be delivered to the Mayor, the President of the City Council, and the Board of Estimates.

para.heading: Examination by Board of Estimates.
para.text: The Board of Estimates may examine, at any time, the Authority's books, accounts, and records.

section.heading: Tax exemption.
section.text: To the fullest extent permitted under the Enabling Act, all of the Authority's property is exempt from taxation of every kind and nature whatsoever.

para.text: Subject to the requirements of this section, the Authority may engage in borrowings in furtherance of its purposes and powers.
No borrowing may involve the issuance by the Authority of any public bonds.

para.heading: Security for a borrowing.
para.text: The Authority may secure any borrowing to the fullest extent permitted by the Enabling Act.
Each borrowing must be approved by resolution of the Authority's Board of Directors in accordance with the procedures in the Enabling Act for the approval of revenue bonds.

Each borrowing must also be approved by the Board of Estimates and the Board of Finance, which approval must specify all material matters with respect to the borrowing (e.g., issue date, maturity, interest rate, terms, form, denominations, manner of execution, place of payment, redemption, refunding, and security provided).

section.heading: Compliance with other City laws and regulations.

para.heading: Building, zoning, and similar requirements.
para.text: Any parking project developed by the Authority must be built under the laws, rules, and regulations of the City. The Authority must obtain all building, zoning, and other similar permits, where required, and must pay all applicable permit fees.

para.heading: Historical and architectural preservation.
para.text: For any parking project on or proposed for a site that is located within an Historical and Architectural Preservation District or that is on the Landmark List or Potential-Landmark List, the Authority must comply with all requirements of City Code Article 6 {"Historical and Architectural Preservation"}.

para.heading: Minority and Small Business Opportunity Program.
para.text: The Authority is subject to and must comply with the City's Minority and Small Business Opportunity Program.

annotation.text: This subtitle was enacted by Ordinance 13-098, effective February 19, 2013. Sections 3 and 4 of Ord. 13-098 provide as follows
Section 3. And be it further ordained, That this Ordinance applies to all valet parking services to be provided or offered on or after [August 19, 2013].

Section 4. And be it further ordained, That rules and regulations to carry out Article [31], Subtitle 14, as enacted by this Ordinance, shall be adopted [on or before May 21, 2013]. These rules and regulations may provide that, for applications submitted during the 1st year following [February 19, 2013] by hosts or operators who were providing valet parking services before the [February 19, 2013], the Baltimore City Parking Authority may issue short-term, provisional valet parking licenses and the Department of Transportation may issue short-term provisional valet parking zone permits, pending their respective reviews and considerations of the applications, valet parking plans, applicant qualifications, etc. The rules and regulations may further provide that, on approval of an application, full-term licenses shall be issued. Fees for any short-term licenses shall be prorated.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this subtitle, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Attendant.
para.text: "Attendant" means any individual who directs, drives, parks, or otherwise assumes control of a vehicle as part of a valet parking service.

para.heading: Authority.
para.text: "Authority" means the Baltimore City Parking Authority.

para.heading: Board of Directors.
para.text: "Board of Directors' means the Authority's Board of Directors.

para.heading: Contract-operator.
para.text: "Contract-operator" means an operator that provides valet parking services under contract with a host.

para.heading: Director of Transportation.
para.text: "Director of Transportation" means the Director of the Department of Transportation or the Director's designee.

para.heading: Executive Director.
para.text: "Executive Director" means the Executive Director of the Authority or the Executive Director's designee.

para.heading: Host.
para.text: "Host" means any business establishment or other person that offers valet parking services to its patrons, whether:
directly through its own employees or agents; or
indirectly by contract with another person.

para.heading: Host-operator.
para.text: "Host-operator" means a host that provides valet parking services directly through its own employees or agents.
"Operator" means any person that, through its employees or agents, provides or offers to provide valet parking services, whether as a contract-operator or a host operator.
"Operator" includes any host that provides or offers to provide valet parking services through its own employees or agents.

para.heading: Principal.
para.text: "Principal", as used with respect to an operator or host, means:
a sole proprietor of the operator or host;
a partner, officer, or director of the operator or host; or
any stockholder of the operator or host who:
owns more than 25% of the voting stock of the operator or host; or
notwithstanding the percentage of shares owned, has the power to direct or control the direction of the operator's or host's management or policies.
"Valet parking service" means, except as specified in paragraph (3) of this subsection, any of the following acts performed for the benefit of a vehicle's driver:
moving a vehicle from one location to another location for parking; or
returning a vehicle from its parked location to another location for pick-up.
"Valet parking service" includes any act described in paragraph (1) of this subsection, whether:
a fee is charged for the service or not; or
the service is provided by the host directly or by another person under contract with the host.
"Valet parking service" does not include attendant parking at an off-street parking facility.

para.heading: Valet parking zone.
para.text: "Valet parking zone" means a space adjacent to a curb that, during specified times, is reserved exclusively for valet parking services.

annotations.annotation: For the Code-wide, standard uses of mandatory terms (“must” and “shall”), prohibitory terms (“may not”, “must not”, and “no ... may”), and permissive terms (“may”), see City General Provisions Article, § 1-104.

para.heading: Director to adopt.
para.text: Subject to Title 4 {"Administrative Procedure Act – Regulations"} of the City General Provisions Article, the Director of Transportation, in consultation with the Authority, must adopt rules and regulations to carry out this subtitle.

para.heading: Approvals by Board of Estimates.
para.text: The Director of Transportation must obtain prior approval of the Board of Estimates for any rule or regulation that sets an application, license, permit, or other fee to be imposed under this subtitle.

annotations.annotation: By authority of Ordinance 20-431, Section 5, the Director of Legislative Reference, in consultation with the Law Department, has conformed subsection (b) to refer expressly to and reflect the requirements of the recently-enacted Administrative Procedure Act that, effective January 15, 2021, governs the proposal, adoption, and publication of administrative rules and regulations.

para.heading: Full exemption.
para.text: This subtitle does not apply to a temporary valet parking service if:
no professional operator is being used for the service;
no fee is charged to drivers or passengers using the service;
the service is being provided:
at a private residence; or
for a public entity; and
the service is being provided by the host for no more than 3 days in any 12-month period.

para.heading: Partial exemption.
para.text: If a professional operator is being used for the service, but all of the other conditions specified in subsection (a) of this section are met:
a parking zone permit under Part III of this subtitle is not required for the service;
the operator must be licensed under Part II of this subtitle and, except as provided in item (3) of this subsection, must comply with all other applicable requirements of this subtitle; and

with the approval of the Director of Transportation, the Executive Director may allow the operator to use public rights-of-way for parking, subject to the issuance of all permits otherwise required for the use of public rights-of-way.

section.heading: License required.
section.text: No operator may provide or offer to provide any valet parking service without first having obtained an operator's license from the Authority.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: To qualify for an operator's license, an applicant must meet the requirements of this section.

para.heading: Prior infractions.
para.text: Neither the applicant nor any of the applicant's principals, employees, attendants or other agents may have committed an act or omission within the preceding 12 months that, under § 14-41 of this subtitle, is cause for the denial, suspension, or revocation of an operator's license.
The applicant must have and maintain liability insurance coverage that covers, as insured parties:
the applicant;
all hosts for which the operator is or may become under contract during the term of the license; and
the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore.
The coverage provided must be of the type and for the amount that the City's Office of Risk Management reasonably prescribes.

para.heading: Form.
para.text: An application for an operator's license must be submitted in the form required by the rules and regulations adopted under this subtitle.
The application must be accompanied by a non-refundable application fee to cover the cost of investigating and processing the application.
The amount of the fee is as set forth in the rules and regulations adopted under this subtitle.

para.heading: Contents.
para.text: The application must contain:
the applicant's full legal name and any trade name(s) under which it operates;
the street address, telephone number, and email address of the applicant's principal place of business;
the street address, telephone number, and email address of any other of the applicant's places of business in the City;
the names, street addresses, telephone numbers, and email addresses of the applicant's principals;
proof of insurance in the form and amount required under § 14-8(c) {"Qualifications: Liability insurance"} of this subtitle;
a statement as to whether the applicant proposes to provide valet parking services as a host-operator or as a contract-operator;

a listing of all valet parking licenses or valet parking permits issued to the applicant or to any principal of the applicant within the preceding 5 years, whether by the City or any other jurisdiction;
a list of all hosts in the City or any other jurisdiction that have used the applicant's services within the preceding 2 years;

certification that neither the applicant nor any of the applicant's principals, employees, attendants or other agents have committed an act or omission within the preceding 12 months that, under § 14-41 of this subtitle, is cause for the denial, suspension, or revocation of an operator's license;
certification that each attendant employed by the applicant:
possesses a valid driver's license; and
is 18 years old or older; and
any other information required by the rules and regulations adopted under this subtitle.

para.heading: Signature and verification.
para.text: The application must be signed, under oath or affirmation, subject to the penalties of perjury, by the applicant as follows:
if for a sole proprietorship, by its owner;
if for a partnership, by an authorized partner; and
if for a corporation, limited liability company, or similar entity, by an authorized officer.

section.heading: Issuance.
section.text: The Authority must issue a license to any applicant who :

para.text: meets the requirements of this subtitle; and
pays the applicable license fee.

para.heading: Term.
para.text: An operator's license expires on the 1st anniversary of its effective date and is renewable as provided in this section.
To renew an operator's license, the licensee must apply no less than 60 nor more than 90 days before the license expires.
The application for renewal must be in the form and contain the information required by the rules and regulations adopted under this subtitle.

section.heading: License fees.
section.text: The annual license fee is as set forth in the rules and regulations adopted under this subtitle.

section.heading: License not transferable.
section.text: An operator's license issued under this part is not assignable or transferable to any other person.

section.heading: List of licensees.
section.text: The Parking Authority must:

para.text: maintain a list of all current licensees; and
provide the Department of Transportation with a copy the list whenever it is updated.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: No host may provide or offer to provide any valet parking service that uses any portion of a public right-of-way for drop-off, pick-up, parking, or temporary stopping or standing, except in compliance with a valet parking zone permit issued under this subtitle.

para.heading: Issuance.
para.text: A valet parking zone permit may be issued by the Authority, with the approval of the Director of Transportation.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: To qualify for a valet parking zone permit, a host must meet the requirements of this Part III.

para.heading: Operator's license.
para.text: The host must:
hold a valid operator's license issued under Part II of this subtitle; or
provide all valet parking services under contract with an operator that holds a valid operator's license issued under Part II of this subtitle.

para.heading: Prior infractions.
para.text: Neither the host, operator, nor any of the host's or operator's principals, employees, attendants, or other agents may have committed an act or omission within the preceding 12 months that, under § 14-41 or § 14-42 of this subtitle, is cause for the denial, suspension, or revocation of an operator's license or a valet zone parking permit.

para.heading: Form.
para.text: An application for a valet parking zone permit must be submitted by the host in the form required by the rules and regulations adopted under this subtitle.
The application must be accompanied by a non-refundable application fee to cover the cost of investigating and processing the application.
The amount of the fee is as set forth in the rules and regulations adopted under this subtitle.

para.heading: Contents.
para.text: The application must contain:
the host's full legal name and any trade name(s) under which it operates;
the street address, telephone number, and email address of the host's principal place of business;
the location at which the host proposes to provide valet parking services;
the nature of the business or other activity conducted by the host at that location;
if the host will be providing the valet parking services through its own employees and agents, the identification number of its host-operator's application or license under Part II of this subtitle;
if the host will be providing the valet parking services under contract with an operator, the identification number of the contract-operator's license issued under Part II of this subtitle;
a valet parking plan for the location that complies with § 14-19 {"Valet parking plan"} of this subtitle;

certification that neither the applicant nor any of the applicant's principals, employees, attendants or other agents have committed an act or omission within the preceding 12 months that, under § 14-41 of this subtitle, is cause for the denial, suspension, or revocation of an operator's license; and
any other information required by the rules and regulations adopted under this subtitle.
The application must be signed, under oath or affirmation, subject to the penalties of perjury, by:
the host; and
any contract-operator to be used to provide the service.
The individual signing on behalf of the host or a contract-operator must be:
if for a sole proprietorship, its owner;
if for a partnership, an authorized partner; and
if for a corporation, limited liability company, or similar entity, an authorized officer.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The application must be accompanied by a valet parking plan that contains the following information.

para.heading: Times of operation; occupancy.
para.text: The plan must specify:
the days of the week and the hours of those days during which valet parking services will be provided; and
the host's seating or other occupancy capacity.
The plan must include photographs of the proposed valet parking zone, including the curb space and roadway.
The number of photographs and the views to be shown are as set forth in the rules and regulations adopted under this subtitle.

para.heading: Pattern of drop-off and pick-up.
para.text: The Plan must describe the proposed pattern of drop-off and pick-up of vehicles.
The plan must identify, by name, address, telephone number, and, if available, email address, the off-street parking facility at which vehicles will be parked.
The parking facility must be:
licensed to the extent required by City Code Article 15, Subtitle 12 {"Parking Facilities"}; and
located within a 1-mile radius of the valet parking zone.

Unless the parking facility is on the host's premises or otherwise owned or controlled by the host, the plan must include a copy of the lease or other agreement that authorizes the facility's use for valet parking services.
The lease or other agreement must specify:
the total number of parking spaces at the facility; and
the number of those spaces that are set aside for the exclusive use of vehicles from the valet parking service.

para.heading: Traffic flow.
para.text: The plan must specify the route(s) to be driven between the valet parking zone and the off-street parking facility.

para.heading: Number of vehicles, employees.
para.text: The plan must state:
the estimated number of vehicles that will be valet parked during each hour of operation; and
the estimated number of employees or agents that will provide valet parking services during each hour of operation.

para.heading: Site manager.
para.text: The plan must provide the name(s), the daytime and nighttime telephone numbers, and the email address(es) of the individual(s) who will manage the valet parking services at the location.

para.heading: Notice to public.
para.text: The plan must contain verification that advance written notice of the application and valet parking plan has been provided to:
the owners of the properties adjoining the host property;
the owners of the properties immediately across the street from the host property;
the neighborhood associations on file with the Department of Planning as representing the affected area; and
the Councilmember(s) who represent the affected area.

para.heading: Other information.
para.text: The plan must include any other information required by the rules and regulations adopted under this subtitle.

para.heading: Posting required.
para.text: On filing an application and valet parking plan for a permit (other than a renewal permit), the applicant must post the proposed host property for 15 days, in accordance with the rules and regulations adopted under this subtitle.

para.heading: 9 or fewer objections.
para.text: If, within the 15-day posting period, the Director of Transportation receives no more than 9 written objections from property owners or residents within the same election precinct as the proposed host property, the valet parking zone permit may be issued as provided in this subtitle.

If, within the 15-day posting period, the Director of Transportation receives 10 or more written objections from property owners or residents within the same election precinct as the proposed host property, the Director of Transportation must hold a hearing on the matter.
Unless the applicant agrees to a later date, the hearing must be held within 15 days after the last day of the 15-day posting period.
Written notice of the hearing shall be provided by first class mail at least 15 days prior to the hearing to all persons listed in § 14-19(i) of this subtitle.
At the hearing, parties in interest and citizens must be given an opportunity to be heard.
The Director of Transportation must notify the applicant in writing of his or her decision to grant or deny the permit as follows:
if no hearing is held under § 14-20(c) of this subtitle, within 15 days after the last day of the 15-day posting period; and
if a hearing is held under § 14-20(c) of this subtitle, within 15 days after conclusion of the hearing.
Any denial of a permit must be based solely on the qualifications, standards, and considerations set forth in this subtitle.
A notice of denial must:
specify the reasons for the denial; and
notify the applicant of the opportunity to appeal the denial of the permit under § 14-46 {"Administrative appeals"} of this subtitle.

para.heading: Review.
para.text: The Executive Director must:
review the valet parking plan for compliance with this subtitle; and
submit the plan, together with his or her findings and recommendations, to the Director of Transportation for approval or disapproval.

para.heading: Minimum findings.
para.text: A valet parking plan may be approved only if:
the valet parking services will not unreasonably disrupt vehicular and pedestrian traffic;
the valet parking services will not pose a threat to public safety; and
the valet parking plan provides for enough attendants and other employees and agents to efficiently handle the projected number of vehicles during all hours of valet parking services.

para.heading: Additional considerations.
para.text: The following criteria may also be considered in deciding whether to approve a valet parking plan:
the number of off-street parking spaces that will be available during valet parking services;
normal traffic conditions at the time of valet parking services;
the time required to travel safely, on foot and by vehicle, to and from the valet parking zone and the off-street parking facility in which vehicles will be parked;
the estimated number of vehicles that will be parked during each hour of valet parking services;
the average length of time a vehicle will be parked during valet parking hours; and
the distance between the valet parking zone and the off-street parking facility in which vehicles will be parked.

para.heading: Final determination.
para.text: In approving a plan, the Director of Transportation makes the final determination of:
the location of the valet parking zone;
the size of the zone;
the hours of operation; and
the conditions of operation.

para.heading: Indemnification.
para.text: The issuance of a valet parking zone permit is conditioned on receipt of a written agreement by the host and by any contract-operator providing services under the permit that they each, jointly and severally, will save harmless and indemnify the Parking Authority of Baltimore City the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore, and their officers, agents, and employees from all suits, losses, claims, liabilities, damages, or expenses to which any of them is subjected as a result of a valet parking zone permit or the operation of valet parking services.

para.heading: Other conditions.
para.text: The Director of Transportation may impose reasonable limitations and conditions on any valet parking zone permit issued under this part as necessary or proper to:
protect the public safety;
protect the public's right to equal access of public property; and
ensure that normal vehicular and pedestrian traffic flow is not unreasonably disrupted.

section.heading: Establishment of zone; issuance of permit.
section.text: On approval of the application and the valet parking plan, the Director of Transportation may establish a valet parking zone for and issue a valet parking zone permit to any host who:

para.text: commits to abide by an approved valet parking plan;
commits to meet all of the other requirements of this subtitle; and
pays the applicable permit fee.

section.heading: Posting of zone.
section.text: As soon as practical after the approval of a valet parking zone, the Director of Transportation shall place appropriate signs that:

para.text: indicate the location of the zone; and
state the operational hours during which restrictions apply.
Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, a permit issued under this part expires on the 1st anniversary of its effective date and is renewable as provided in this section.
By rule or regulation adopted under this subtitle, the Director of Transportation may provide for the issuance of short-term permits for special events.
To renew an annual permit, the host must apply no less than 60 nor more than 90 days before the license expires.
The application for renewal must be in the form and contain the information required by the rules and regulations adopted under this subtitle.

If, before the end of the renewal period, 10 or more written objections from property owners or residents within the same election precinct as the permitted premises are filed with the Director of Transportation, the Director of Transportation must hold a public hearing on the proposed renewal.
Parties in interest and citizens must be given an opportunity to be heard.
Any denial of a renewal permit must be based solely on the qualifications, standards, and considerations set forth in this subtitle.

section.heading: Permit fees.
section.text: The amount of the permit fees are as set forth in the rules and regulations adopted under this subtitle.

section.heading: Permit not transferable or shareable.
section.text: A permit issued under this part to any host is not assignable or transferable to, or shareable with, any other host not identified in the permit.

section.heading: Licensed operator required.
section.text: No host may use the valet parking services of any entity that is not a licensed operator or of any individual who is not an employee or agent of a licensed operator.

section.heading: Locations and hours.
section.text: Valet parking services may be offered only in the locations and during the hours specified on the valet parking zone permit.

para.heading: Pick-up, drop-off only in zone.
para.text: The drop-off and pick-up of vehicles for valet parking services may be conducted only in a designated valet parking zone.

para.heading: Other uses of zone prohibited.
para.text: During the hours specified in the valet parking zone permit, a valet parking zone may be used only for the immediate drop-off and pick-up of vehicles.

para.heading: Qualifications.
para.text: Every attendant must:
possess a valid driver's license; and
be 18 years old or older.

para.heading: Uniforms.
para.text: Each attendant must wear a uniform top that clearly identifies the operator of the valet service.

para.heading: Removal to parking facility.
para.text: Attendants must immediately remove vehicles from the valet parking zone and take them directly to the applicable off-street parking facility.

para.heading: No leaving in right-of-way.
para.text: The operator, its attendants or other employees or agents, may not park, stop, or leave a vehicle:
on any right-of-way, even if on-street public parking is generally allowed; or
anywhere else other than in the off-street parking facility designated in the valet parking plan.

para.heading: Compliance with traffic laws.
para.text: The operator, its attendants or other employees or agents, must comply with all applicable traffic laws and parking regulations when providing valet parking services.

para.heading: Required.
para.text: During all hours of operation, the operator must prominently display at least 1 sign that identifies:
the operator;
the host for which the operator is working; and
any fee being charged for the valet parking services.

para.heading: Placement, etc.
para.text: All signage must comply with all laws, rules, and regulations governing signs and permits.

section.heading: Permit and operator's license inspection.
section.text: At all times, the valet parking zone permit and a copy of the operator's license must be available for inspection at the host's establishment.

section.heading: Denials, suspensions, or revocations – Operator's license.
section.text: The Parking Authority, subject to the approval of the Director of Transportation, may deny, suspend, or revoke an operator's license or renewal license for any of the following causes:

para.text: making any material false statement in any application for an operator's license or in any application or accompanying valet parking plan for a valet parking zone permit;
failing to pay the applicable license fee on or before its due date;
providing valet parking services in a way that endangers public safety;
providing valet parking services that unreasonably disrupt vehicular or pedestrian traffic;
violating any other provision of this subtitle, of a rule or regulation adopted under this subtitle, or of a limitation or condition imposed on a license or permit issued under this subtitle; or
otherwise failing to meet the qualifications or other requirements of this subtitle for a license.

section.heading: Denials, suspensions, or revocations – Host's parking zone permit.
section.text: The Director of Transportation may deny, suspend, or revoke a valet parking zone permit or renewal permit for any of the following causes:

para.text: making any material false statement in any application or accompanying valet parking plan for a valet parking zone permit;
failing to pay the applicable permit fee on or before its due date;
providing or knowingly or negligently allowing a contract-operator to provide valet parking services in a way that endangers public safety;
providing or knowingly or negligently allowing a contract-operator to provide valet parking services that unreasonably disrupt vehicular or pedestrian traffic;
violating any other provision of this subtitle, of a rule or regulation adopted under this subtitle, or of a limitation or condition imposed on a license or permit issued under this subtitle; or
otherwise failing to meet the qualifications or other requirements of this subtitle for a permit.

section.heading: Cause for suspension or revocation – Enforcement by citation.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In addition to any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement procedure, any violation that is cause for suspending or revoking a license or a permit may be enforced, instead of or in addition to suspending or revoking the license or permit, by issuance of an environmental citation under City Code Article 1, Subtitle 40 {"Environmental Control Board"}.

para.heading: Process not exclusive.
para.text: The issuance of a citation to enforce this subtitle does not preclude pursuing any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement action authorized by law.

para.heading: Right of appeal.
para.text: An aggrieved party may appeal to the Board of Municipal and Zoning Appeals:
the denial, suspension, or revocation of a license or permit;
the imposition of a fine; or
any other decision or ruling under this subtitle.

para.heading: How and when taken.
para.text: The appeal must be taken in writing within 15 days from the date of notice of the denial, suspension, or revocation, fine imposition, or other decision or ruling.

para.heading: Hearing and decision.
para.text: The Board of Municipal and Zoning Appeals:
must hold a hearing on the appeal as soon as practicable but no later than 60 days from the filing of the appeal;
must provide written notice of the hearing by first class mail at least 15 days prior to the hearing to all persons listed in § 14-19(i) of this subtitle; and
may affirm, modify, or reverse the action from which the appeal was taken.

para.heading: Judicial review.
para.text: A party aggrieved by a final decision of the Board of Municipal and Zoning Appeals under § 14-46 {"Administrative appeals"} of this subtitle may seek judicial review of that decision by petition to the Circuit Court for Baltimore City in accordance with the Maryland Rules of Procedure.

para.heading: Appellate review.
para.text: A party to the judicial review may appeal the court's final judgment to the Court of Special Appeals in accordance with the Maryland Rules of Procedure.

section.heading: In general.
section.text: Any person who violates any provision of this subtitle, of a rule or regulation adopted under this subtitle, or of a limitation or condition imposed on a license or permit issued under this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine of not more than $1,000 for each offense.

section.heading: Each day a separate offense.
section.text: Each day that a violation continues is a separate offense.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this subtitle, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Advisory Board.
para.text: "Advisory Board" means the BMore Streets for People Advisory Board established under this subtitle.

para.heading: BMore Streets for People; Program.
para.text: "BMore Streets for People" or "Program" means the BMore Streets for People Program established under this subtitle.

para.heading: Director.
para.text: "Director" means the Director of Transportation or the Director's designee.

section.heading: Program established.
section.text: There is a BMore Streets for People Program.

section.heading: Purpose of program.
section.text: The purpose of the BMore Streets for People Program is to create economic, health, and community benefits by periodically restricting motorized traffic on certain streets in order to encourage residents to enjoy camaraderie, bicycle riding, walking, and exercise on main roads in their neighborhoods.

section.heading: DOT to administer.
section.text: The Program is administered by the Department of Transportation, with the advice of the BMore Streets for People Advisory Board.

section.heading: Rules and regulations.
section.text: Subject to Title 4 {"Administrative Procedure Act – Regulations"} of the City General Provisions Article, the Department of Transportation may adopt rules and regulations to:

para.text: implement the Program; and
otherwise carry out this subtitle.

annotations.annotation: By authority of Ordinance 20-431, Section 5, the Director of Legislative Reference, in consultation with the Law Department, has conformed this section to refer expressly to the requirements of the recently-enacted Administrative Procedure Act that, effective January 15, 2021, governs the proposal, adoption, and publication of administrative rules and regulations.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In consultation with the Advisory Board, the Director may designate routes and schedules on City streets for the BMore Streets for People Program.

para.heading: "Lake to lake" route.
para.text: In consultation with the Advisory Board, the Director will designate an initial "lake to lake" route running from Lake Montebello to Druid Hill Lake.

para.heading: Additional routes.
para.text: Additional routes may be designated under this section if a neighborhood association requests that it be allowed to host a BMore Streets for People event in its neighborhood.

section.heading: Exclusion of motor vehicles.
section.text: The Director may exclude motor vehicles from streets along designated BMore Streets for People routes during Program events, in accordance with the Department of Transportation's permit process.

section.heading: Regular processes to apply.
section.text: Nothing in this subtitle should be constructed as waiving the usual permitting processes, or fees for public services required to ensure safety, that would otherwise be required to conduct the Program.

section.heading: Board established.
section.text: There is a BMore Streets for People Advisory Board.

para.text: The Advisory Board consists of 26 members.
Of these:
19 members are appointed by the Mayor in accordance with Article IV, § 6 of the Baltimore City Charter; and
7 members are agency representatives.

para.heading: Appointed members.
para.text: The 19 appointed members of the Advisory Board are as follows:
2 at-large members;
4 members nominated by community organizations and appointed by the Mayor, 1 from each of the following organizations:
One Less Car;
Roland Park Civic League;
Mayor's Bicycle Advisory Committee; and
a non-profit organization or foundation with a history of support for the BMore Streets for People Program, the Program's cyclovia model, and the Program's Sunday Streets predecessor.
3 members nominated by neighborhood associations representing neighborhoods along any proposed BMore Streets for People Route and appointed by the Mayor.
10 members recommended by the President of the City Council, as follows:
1 from the neighborhoods along the proposed "lake -to-lake" (Montebello to Druid Hill) route;
4 from neighborhood associations;
1 from local business associations;
2 from local religious institutions, non-profit organizations, or foundations with knowledge of and support for the BMore Streets for People Program; and
2 from schools.

para.heading: Agency representatives.
para.text: The 7 agency representatives are the following, or their designated representatives:
the Director of Transportation;
the Health Commissioner;
the Director of the Baltimore Office of Promotion and the Arts;
the Director of the Office of Sustainability;
the Director of the Office of Neighborhoods;
the Police commissioner; and
the Executive Director of the Baltimore City Parking Authority.
Advisory Board Members serve for a term of 4 years, concurrent with the terms of the Mayor and the City Council.
At the end of a term, an Advisory Board member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.

para.heading: Compensation; expenses.
para.text: The members of the Advisory Board:
serve without compensation; but
are entitled to reimbursement for reasonable expenses incurred in the performance of their duties, as provided in the Ordinance of Estimates.

para.heading: Vacancies.
para.text: A member appointed to fill a vacancy in an unexpired term serves only for the remainder of that term
The Mayor must designate a member of the Advisory Board to serve as its Chair.
Members of the Advisory Board may select any other officers they consider necessary or appropriate.

para.heading: Committees.
para.text: The Chair may appoint committees to assist the Advisory Board in carrying out its functions and duties.
The Advisory Board may meet, at the call of the Chair, as frequently as required to perform its duties.
A majority of the members of the Advisory Board constitutes a quorum for the transaction of business.
An affirmative vote by the majority of a quorum is needed for any official action.

para.heading: Rules of procedure.
para.text: The Advisory Board may adopt rules of procedure to govern its meetings and procedures.

para.heading: Failure to attend meetings.
para.text: If any member is absent from regularly scheduled meetings more than 3 times in 1 year, not counting absences excused by the Chair:
the member is considered to have resigned; and
the Chair must recommend for appointment by the Mayor, a replacement member with similar qualifications to the resigning member.

section.heading: Budget.
section.text: The Advisory Board may expend funds as authorized in the Ordinance of Estimates.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The BMore Streets for People Advisory Board may undertake the activities described in this section.

para.heading: Routing and programming.
para.text: The Advisory Board may:
propose pilot and permanent routes for the BMore Streets for People Program; and
recommend programming enhancements and other services when a need for them is determined by the Advisory Board.

para.heading: Advice.
para.text: The Advisory Board may make recommendations about solutions and alternatives for routing challenges, programming, communication strategies, and the cost effective use of City personnel.

para.heading: Research and education.
para.text: To gauge the impact of the BMore Streets for People Program on participating communities, the Advisory Board must research and measure the following in neighborhoods along Program routes:
level of community participation in BMore Streets for People planning and implementation;
diversity of participation among age groups and nonprofit organizations; and
evidence of enhanced sociability and healthy activities.

para.heading: Monitor program.
para.text: The Advisory Board may:
review and monitor the successes and lessons learned in conducting the BMore Streets for People Program in Baltimore City; and
make recommendations for promoting the efforts of the Program.

para.heading: Advise and counsel.
para.text: The Advisory Board may:
provide education to the residents of Baltimore City, the City Council, the Mayor, and the various departments and agencies of the City on Program activities and outcomes; and
recommend programs and legislation to promote and ensure the continued success and expansion of the Program throughout Baltimore City.

para.heading: Evaluate policies and programs.
para.text: The Advisory Board may review and evaluate the impact of existing and proposed policies, programs, and legislation affecting the BMore Streets for People Program.

section.heading: Annual reports.
section.text: The Director and the Advisory Board must submit an annual report on their activities to the Mayor and City Council.

section.heading: Slowly moving vehicles.
section.text: Vehicles moving slowly along streets having no car tracks shall keep as close as practicable to the curb line on the right so as to allow faster moving vehicles free passage on the left.

section.heading: Snow tires on public passenger vehicles.

para.heading: Winter-type mud and snow tire defined.
para.text: For the purposes of this section, a winter-type mud and snow tire is any new, recapped, retreaded, or rebuilt tire for the rear wheels of motor vehicles or trackless trolleys having anti-skid patterns impressed or cut into the treaded surfaces to form bars, buttons, or blocks which may contain perforations, ingredients, or metallic elements specially designed to give effective traction on snow-, mud-, or ice-covered streets; and which tire is subject to approval as to type and condition by the Director of Transportation.

para.heading: When required.
para.text: It is unlawful for any non-fixed wheel vehicle for the public transportation of passengers for a fee or charge, including the vehicles commonly referred to as buses, trackless trolley, and taxicabs, to be or operate on any street or public place in Baltimore City during the period in any year commencing on November 1 and ending on the following April 1 without being properly equipped with winter-type mud and snow tires.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Any person, firm, or corporation violating the provisions of this section shall be subject to the general penalties provided in this article, and a violation as to each and every vehicle is a separate violation.

section.heading: Obstructions by certain public passenger vehicles for want of chains or snow tires.

para.heading: Director to regulate.
para.text: Subject to Title 4 {"Administrative Procedure Act – Regulations"} of the City General Provisions Article, the Director of Transportation may adopt rules and regulations to require that, whenever certain named streets in the City are covered or partially covered with snow, sleet, or freezing rain, no non-fixed wheel vehicle for the public transportation of 10 or more people may operate on those streets in a manner that stalls, impedes, or obstructs traffic, if that stalling, impeding, or obstructing is caused by the failure to equip the vehicle with effective skid chains or effective snow tread tires.
Every separate stalling, impeding, or obstructing on such named streets and in violation of any applicable such rules or regulation, shall be considered a separate offense.

Upon conviction thereof, the person, firm, or corporation which owns and/or manages the public transportation business in which the particular vehicle is operated shall be subject to a fine of not exceeding $50 for each and every offense.

annotations.annotation: By authority of Ordinance 20-431, Section 5, the Director of Legislative Reference, in consultation with the Law Department, has conformed subsection (a) to refer expressly to and reflect the requirements of the recently-enacted Administrative Procedure Act that, effective January 15, 2021, governs the proposal, adoption, and publication of administrative rules and regulations.

para.heading: Morning hours.
para.text: Between the hours of 6 a.m. and 7:30 a.m., no vehicle shall be placed to load thereon or unload therefrom in which the rails of any railroad or street railway company are laid, so as to obstruct or hinder the passing of cars of any such railroad or street railway.

para.heading: Other times.
para.text: Nor at any other time shall any such vehicle be permitted to obstruct such tracks for a longer period than may be reasonably necessary for the purpose of loading or unloading said vehicle.

It shall be unlawful for any person to make any repairs to a motor vehicle or to replace or repair any tire or other part of a motor vehicle on any public street where the standing of such vehicle or vehicles will wholly or partially obstruct any lane of traffic.

It shall be unlawful for any vehicle in the process of being repaired or waiting to be repaired or any vehicle on which a tire or other part thereof is being replaced or waiting for a tire or other part thereof to be replaced to stand double or to do any work or place any tools or equipment on any sidewalk in connection with the repair of any vehicle or the replacement or repair of any tire or other part thereof.
It shall be unlawful for a motor vehicle repair service to make a repair, replacement, or adjustment to a motor vehicle or part of a motor vehicle on any public street or footway.

para.heading: Emergency repairs excepted.
para.text: The provisions of this section shall not apply to emergency repairs, which are defined as repairs necessary as the result of an unexpected malfunction or breakdown and which are necessary in order to move the vehicle safely and without damage to same.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Any person violating any of the provisions of this section shall be subject to:

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Any person violating paragraph (a)(1) or (a)(2) of this section shall be subject to:
a penalty of not less than $5 or more than $25 for the 1st offense; and
a fine of not less than $25 nor more than $100 for subsequent offenses.

para.heading: Repair in street or footway.
para.text: Any person who violates paragraph (a)(3) of this section shall be subject to:
a penalty of not less than $100 or more than $250 for the 1st offense; and
a fine of not less than $250 nor more than $350 for subsequent offenses.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: It shall be unlawful for the driver of any vehicle to enter a street intersection or a marked crosswalk or to drive across a sidewalk in entering or leaving a garage or parking lot unless there is sufficient space beyond the intersection or crosswalk on the right half of the roadway or in the garage or on the parking lot to accommodate the vehicle he is driving or operating without obstructing the passage of other vehicles or pedestrians, notwithstanding any traffic control signal indication to proceed.

para.heading: Exception for 1-way streets.
para.text: Except that on a 1-way street, drivers shall not be restricted to the use of the right half of the road but may have access to the entire width thereof beyond the intersection or crosswalk provided sufficient space be available.

para.heading: Prohibited conduct.
para.text: No person may back, draw, move, propel, drive, or operate any motor vehicle of any kind or any vehicle of any kind that is drawn by a horse or mule on or over any sidewalk or curbing of the City unless:
the curbing is lowered to grade and the sidewalk so paved and arranged as to allow the passage of these vehicles; or
the person has special permission to do so from the Director of Transportation.
In addition to any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement procedure, this section may be enforced by issuance of:
an environmental citation under City Code Article 1, Subtitle 40 {"Environmental Control Board"}; or
a civil citation under City Code Article 1, Subtitle 41 {"Civil Citations"}.
The issuance of a citation to enforce this section does not preclude pursuing any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement action authorized by law.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Any person who violates any provision of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor, and on conviction, is subject to a fine of not more than $100 for each offense.

section.heading: Vehicles on sidewalk, crosswalk, or intersection.

para.heading: Prohibited conduct.
para.text: It shall not be lawful for any public cartman, or for any person driving or having charge of any public cart, wagon, or other vehicle, to:
drive or back any such public cart or any other cart, wagon, or other vehicle on to the sidewalk of any of the streets of said City, except as hereinafter provided;
stop any such cart, or any other vehicle, on any of the crosswalks or intersections of streets so as to obstruct or hinder the travel along such crosswalks or intersections of street; or

place any such carts or other vehicles crosswise of any street of said city except to load thereon or unload therefrom, but in no case shall it be lawful for any person to permit such cart or other vehicle to remain so crosswise of any street for a longer period than may be actually necessary for such purposes.

para.heading: Exception.
para.text: But it shall be lawful for the owner or occupant of any store, warehouse, or building in any street or avenue in which the rails of any railroad company are laid so close to the curbstones as to prevent the owners or occupants from keeping any such cart or other vehicle in the carriageway in front of his place of business without interference with the passing cars of any such railroad company, to occupy with such cart or other vehicle during business hours so much of the sidewalk as may be necessary for such cart or other vehicle, provided that sufficient space be retained for the passage of pedestrians between the cart or other vehicle so permitted to occupy such portion of the sidewalk and the front of every such store, warehouse, or other building.

section.heading: Vehicles or horses on sidewalk.
section.text: No horse or vehicle shall be driven, backed, led, or allowed to stand on any sidewalk, or on any driveway across a sidewalk, whether with or without curbs, except that wares or merchandise in process of loading and unloading, shipment, or being received from shipment, may be transferred from trucks or other vehicles over the sidewalk by the use of skids, provided a passageway be kept open for the free passage of pedestrians.

para.heading: Compliance with directions. required.
para.text: The driver of every vehicle and the operator of every street car and trackless trolley on the streets and public ways of this City shall comply with any lawful order or direction of any school crossing guard vested with authority by the Police Commissioner to direct, control, or regulate pedestrian or vehicular traffic.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Any person failing to comply with any such lawful order or direction or in any other manner violating the provisions of this section, shall be subject to a fine not to exceed $100 for each offense.

para.heading: Subject to traffic rules.
para.text: Where the Board of School Commissioners and the Director of Transportation jointly designate particular public school properties, the roadways on those properties that are open to the use of the public are, on the placing of appropriate traffic-control devices, subject to the same vehicle and traffic laws, rules, and regulations that apply to highways within the City.

para.heading: Section not a dedication.
para.text: Nothing herein contained shall be construed as dedicating the aforementioned roadways by the City or as meaning that any City or State agency other than the Department of Education of the City of Baltimore shall defray or aid in defraying the costs of maintaining or marking the roadways.

annotations.annotation: Ordinance 04-854 repealed former § 16-23 {“Selling food near schools”} and rewrote City Code Article 15, Subtitle 17, to include a similar provision.

section.heading: School vehicle violations of camera monitoring systems.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this section, "school vehicle" means any motor vehicle that:
is used for the transportation of children, students, or teachers for educational purposes; and
is either:
registered as a Type I school vehicle, as defined in State Transportation Article § 11-173, or as a Type II school vehicle, as defined in State Transportation Article § 11-174; or
otherwise discernable by color or markings as a school vehicle.

para.heading: Inclusions.
para.text: "School vehicle" includes any motor vehicle that is of a type described in paragraph (1) of this section, whether owned and operated by a non-governmental entity or owned or leased by or under contract with a governmental entity.

para.heading: Periodic reports required.
para.text: The Department of Transportation, with assistance from the Department of Finance, shall prepare and submit to the Mayor, the President of the City Council, and the City Board of School Commissioners, or their respective designees, periodic reports on all citations or warnings issued to school vehicles under:
State Transportation Article § 21-202.1 {"Traffic control signal monitoring systems"}; and
City Code Article 32, Subtitle 33 {"Speed Monitoring Systems"}.

para.heading: Contents of reports.
para.text: Each report shall contain:
a copy of all citations or warnings issued for violations by school vehicles during the reporting period;
the disposition of the citations (e.g., pending, paid, overdue, on appeal, or charges dismissed); and
any changes in the disposition of citations that had been the subject of previous reports.

para.heading: Reporting periods.
para.text: Each report shall be submitted on a quarter-annual basis, within 30 days after the end of each quarter, for the quarters ending September 30, December 31, March 31, and June 30 of each fiscal year.

section.heading: Helmets required.
section.text: Every person who is driving, or riding on as a passenger, a moving motor-driven 2- or 3-wheel vehicle known generally as a motorcycle or motor bike shall at such time be wearing a firm and durable protective helmet or headgear.

section.heading: Safety goggles required.
section.text: Every person who is driving or riding as a passenger on a moving motor-driven 2- or 3-wheel vehicle known generally as a motorcycle or motor bike shall at all times be wearing safety goggles or a face shield approved by the Director of Transportation.

section.heading: Must be able to achieve top legal speed.
section.text: No person shall operate a motor-driven 2- or 3-wheel vehicle known generally as a motorcycle or motor bike on the streets or highways of Baltimore City unless its speed capability is at least equal to the posted speed limit on said highway.

section.heading: Penalties.
section.text: A violation of any provision of this subtitle is a misdemeanor, punishable upon conviction by a fine of not less than $10 or more than $100 for each such violation.

section.heading: Crossing procession prohibited.
section.text: It shall be unlawful for any person to drive any vehicle across the line of a funeral procession in the streets, lanes, or alleys of the City, under a penalty for each and every offense of $2.

annotation.doc: City of Balt., Md., Rev. Ords. 1858-032

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The driver of a vehicle shall yield the right-of-way, slowing or stopping if need be, in order to yield to a pedestrian lawfully crossing a roadway within a crosswalk when:
the pedestrian is upon the half of the roadway upon which the vehicle is traveling; or
the pedestrian is approaching so closely from the opposite half of the roadway as to be in danger from the vehicle.

para.heading: Turning vehicle.
para.text: The driver of a vehicle making a right or left turn shall yield the right-of-way, slowing or stopping if need be, in order to yield to a pedestrian lawfully crossing a roadway within a crosswalk when:
the pedestrian is upon the half of the roadway upon which said turning vehicle is entering, or
the pedestrian is approaching so closely from the half of the roadway opposite to that upon which said turning vehicle is entering as to be in danger from the vehicle.

para.heading: Pedestrian's duty.
para.text: A pedestrian shall not suddenly leave a curb or other place of safety and walk or run into the path of a vehicle which is so close that it is impossible for the driver to yield as otherwise required in this section.

section.heading: Emergency vehicles right-of-way.
section.text: Pedestrians shall yield the right-of-way to authorized emergency vehicles provided that these vehicles are operating with siren and/or bell.

para.heading: Overtaking stopped vehicle prohibited.
para.text: If a vehicle is stopped at a marked or unmarked crosswalk to permit a pedestrian to cross a roadway, the driver of any other vehicle approaching from the rear shall not overtake and pass the stopped vehicle.

para.heading: Obstructing crosswalk prohibited.
para.text: No person shall stop or park any vehicle in such manner as to obstruct a crosswalk.

para.heading: "Walk" signal.
para.text: While a "Walk" signal indication is displayed:
pedestrians may proceed across the roadway toward said indication within any marked or unmarked crosswalk; or
where an exclusive all-pedestrian interval is provided, pedestrians may proceed across the roadway in any direction within the intersection.

para.heading: "Wait" or "Don't Walk" signal — pedestrian not yet on roadway.

para.text: While a "Wait" or "Don't Walk" signal indication, whether flashing or steady, controlling their direction of travel is displayed, pedestrians shall not enter the roadway.
In the case of an exclusive all-pedestrian interval, pedestrians shall not enter a roadway while any "Wait" or "Don't Walk" signal indication, whether flashing or steady, is displayed.
This provision is to be effective between the hours of 7 a.m. and 7 p.m. only.

para.heading: "Wait" or "Don't Walk" signal — pedestrian already on roadway.
para.text: Any pedestrian who has entered an intersection on the "Walk" signal indication shall proceed without delay to a sidewalk or safety zone while the "Wait" or "Don't Walk" signal indication is showing.

para.heading: "Controlled access highway" defined.
para.text: For the purpose of this section, "controlled access highway" shall mean every highway, street, or roadway in respect to which owners or occupants of abutting lands and other persons have no legal right of access to or from the same except at such points only and in such manner as may be determined by the public authority having jurisdiction over such highway, street, or roadway.

para.heading: Entry by pedestrian prohibited.
para.text: No pedestrian shall be permitted to enter upon any controlled access highway nor any ramp or access road leading to or from any controlled access highway.

No pedestrian shall debark from any vehicle proceeding upon any controlled access highway nor any ramp or access road leading to or from any controlled access highway except under emergency circumstances which preclude the possibility that the vehicle in which he is riding proceed in a reasonable and proper manner.
In such case, said pedestrian may proceed only to the nearest emergency telephone. He may not solicit a ride or assistance from any passing vehicle.

para.heading: Prohibited conduct – In general.
para.text: No person shall stand within a highway for the purpose of soliciting a ride, employment, or business from the occupant of any vehicle or for the purpose of presenting a gift to or performing a service, whether gratuitous or for a fee, for the occupant of a vehicle.

para.heading: Prohibited conduct – Parents or guardians of minors.
para.text: No parent or guardian shall knowingly permit any minor under the age of 18 years to violate the provisions of subsection (a) of this section.

para.heading: Exception.
para.text: This section does not prohibit the solicitation by any person for lawful employment or business from the occupant of any vehicle which is properly and lawfully parked or properly and lawfully standing out of the free flow of traffic.

A police officer who finds any person 18 years of age or older violating provisions of subsection (a) of this section shall order the person to cease and desist. Persons failing to comply with this order may be issued a citation containing their signed promise to pay the fine provided or to appear in court for trial.
The officer is not required to take the person into physical custody for the violation unless:
the person charged does not furnish satisfactory evidence of identity; or
the officer has reasonable grounds to believe the person charged will disregard a written promise to appear.
A person receiving a citation under this section shall pay the fine provided for in the citation to the District Court of Maryland for Baltimore City, or stand trial for the violation.
A police officer who finds any person under 18 years of age violating provisions of subsection (a) of this section shall order the person to cease and desist.
Any person under 18 years of age who fails to comply with this order:
may be taken into custody; and
subsequent to recording information necessary to carry out the purposes of this section, shall be promptly released to their parent or guardian.
The released person under 18 years of age shall be referred to the Baltimore City Police Department's court sanctioned pre-intake adjustment program.

Any parent or guardian who shall violate subsection (b) of this section after having received written notice of their child or ward having committed a violation of subsection (a) occurring within the preceding 12 months, may receive a written citation and is subject to a fine of $50 for each offense.

Any person 18 years of age or older violating the provisions of subsection (a) of this section after being ordered to cease and desist is guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, shall be fined $50.

section.heading: Control of traffic by officers.
section.text: Nothing in this subtitle affects or limits the right of police officers or school crossing guards to control vehicular and pedestrian traffic in cases of emergency, special events, or other unusual traffic conditions.

section.heading: Exercise of due care.
section.text: In addition to the foregoing provisions of this subtitle, every driver of a vehicle shall:

para.text: exercise due care to avoid colliding with any pedestrian upon any highway; and
exercise proper precautions upon observing any child or confused or incapacitated person upon a highway.

section.heading: Pedestrian traffic safety.
section.text: The Director of Transportation shall:

para.text: identify intersections commonly used by the elderly, the disabled, or other persons who may need extra time to cross an intersection;

conduct studies of those intersections, using pedestrian accident statistics, direct observation, or other sources of information, to determine the need for extra time for pedestrian crossing and the length of time needed; and
wherever feasible, reset the timing of traffic signals or make other adjustments to the intersection to accommodate the need for extra time for pedestrian crossing.

section.heading: Maximum outside width.
section.text: Pursuant to the provisions of § 24-102(d) of the State Transportation Article, the operation within the corporate limits of Baltimore City of a motor bus or trackless trolley with a maximum outside width of not to exceed 102 inches is permitted.

para.text: The Company or companies operating public passenger vehicles, trackless trolleys, or street railway cars discharging passengers within Baltimore City at bus, trackless trolley, or street railway car "Stops", heretofore or hereafter established, by public motor vehicles, trackless trolleys, or by street railway cars upon fixed routes shall, at its or their expense, maintain at each "Stop" the area or space of ground within the footway area of the streets adjacent to or within said "Stops", as designated and approved by the Director of Transportation and in a manner and with material approved by the Director, for the protection, safety, health, and welfare of the public of Baltimore City.
