section.heading: Auction sales – Dirt bikes, unregistered motorcycles, etc.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this section, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Abandoned vehicle.
para.text: "Abandoned vehicle" has the meaning stated in § 25-201(b) of the State Transportation Article.

para.heading: Dirt bike.
para.text: "Dirt bike" has the meaning stated in Article 19, § 40-1 of the City Code.

para.heading: Unregistered motorcycle or similar vehicle.
para.text: "Unregistered motorcycle or similar vehicle" has the meaning stated in Article 19, § 40-1 of the City Code.

para.heading: Bidders must be licensed.
para.text: Bidders for dirt bikes or for unregistered motorcycles or similar vehicles, other than abandoned vehicles, must be licensed, bonded motorcycle dealers, licensed automotive dismantlers and recyclers, or licensed scrap metal dealers.

The purpose of this subsection is to ensure that dirt bikes and unregistered motorcycles or similar vehicles that have been forfeited under City Code Article 19, Subtitle 40, can be put to good use without being returned to the streets of the City.

Forfeited dirt bikes and unregistered motorcycles or similar vehicles may be transferred to 1 or more charitable organizations for export abroad to provide relief to impoverished areas with critical transportation needs.
The procedures used for transfers under this subsection must:
accord with the City Charter provisions that govern the disposition of surplus property;
ensure that all interested charitable organizations have an opportunity submit proposals for the vehicles;
ensure that the selected organization has the ability to take control of the vehicles and export them; and
require the selected organization to enter into a written agreement with the City that delineates the parties' respective responsibilities.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Funds received pursuant to the sales shall be accounted for and remitted to the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore.

para.heading: Claim for excess over expenses.
para.text: However if the owner or person entitled to possession presents to the Director of Transportation, within 90 days of the date of the sale, a claim for any excess in the amount of the selling price of a vehicle, part of a vehicle, or the contents of a vehicle, over and above the expenses, the Director, on finding that an excess of $25 or more exists, shall recommend to the Board of Estimates that the excess be returned to the owner or other person.

para.heading: Priority of expenses.
para.text: Expenses above referred to shall include but not be limited to:
towing;
storage;
unpaid fines against the owner; and
payment of all liens on the vehicle of which the Director received actual notice,
in the above order of priority.

para.heading: Decision of Board final and nonappealable.
para.text: Action of the Board of Estimates upon a recommendation shall be final and not subject to appeal.

section.heading: Purchaser to obtain new title.
section.text: On the sale of a motor vehicle, the Director of Transportation shall forward to the Motor Vehicle Administration a certificate that the motor vehicle has been sold at public auction, with a request that the certificate be considered sufficient evidence to enable the purchaser to obtain a new certificate of title and registration.

para.heading: Scope.
para.text: This section applies to any vehicle that:
was reported stolen; and
is found in and towed from:
an impounding area;
a location where it was obstructing or impeding pedestrian or vehicular traffic; or
an area other than an impounding area, at a location where it was not obstructing or impeding pedestrian or vehicular traffic.

para.heading: Charge abated.
para.text: No charge may be imposed for storing the vehicle during:
the period ending 48 hours after notification by the Towing Division; and
any longer period that, for good cause shown, the Chief approves.
The Chief of the Towing Division shall adopt standards for determining "good cause" under subsection (b)(2) of this section.
A copy of these standards shall be filed with the Department of Legislative Reference before they become effective.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Where the Police Department has caused a vehicle to be impounded for investigative purposes, no storage charges shall be collected.

para.heading: Release of vehicle.
para.text: Upon receiving an order from the Police Department, the Towing Division shall release the vehicle to the owner, his or her next of kin, or his or her authorized representative.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: If a vehicle is impounded and neither the owner nor operator of the vehicle is charged with a violation that falls within the scope of this subtitle, no charge may be imposed for towing or storage if, after every reasonable attempt has been made to notify the owner or the owner's next of kin that the vehicle has been delivered to the storage area, the vehicle is reclaimed within 48 hours or within any longer period that, for good cause shown, the Chief of the Towing Division approves.

para.heading: Exception.
para.text: Subsection (a) of this section does not apply to the impoundment of:
a stolen vehicle;
an abandoned vehicle; or
a vehicle involved in an accident, unless the vehicle was lawfully parked at the time of the accident.

section.heading: Mid-block pedestrian crossings.
section.text: No vehicle shall be permitted to stop or stand at any time within 50 feet of an approach to a mid-block pedestrian crossing or within a distance of 25 feet after leaving a mid-block crossing.

section.heading: Fire houses; emergency vehicle parking area.
section.text: In front of or opposite any fire engine house and in any reservation for authorized emergency vehicles in spaces marked off and designated by the Director of Transportation.

section.heading: Carpool parking.
section.text: Those locations on public metered parking lots set aside for carpool cars by the Director of Transportation.

section.heading: Fire lanes.
section.text: Within any designated fire lane on either public or private property open to the use of the general public.

section.heading: Spaces reserved for disabled and helpers.
section.text: Within any space or zone marked as restricted, pursuant to § 6-9 or §§ 9-1 through 9-15 of this article, to the use of disabled persons or helpers of disabled persons on private or City-owned property open to the use of the general public, except for vehicles with special registration plates for disabled persons.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Within any zone marked as tow away, pursuant to § 6-12 of this article, so as to obstruct or impede egress or ingress to or from a driveway, service drive, or private way.

para.heading: Construction.
para.text: Violation of this section occurs whether or not a vehicle has actually been prevented from entering or leaving the driveway, service drive, or private way.

para.heading: "Car-sharing program" defined.
para.text: "Car-sharing program" means a program by which an entity offers the use of motor vehicles to its members and patrons on a 24-hours-a-day, 7-days-a-week basis, charging for the use of these vehicles on a time-used basis.

para.heading: Impounding area.
para.text: Impounding areas include those locations on the streets, on public-metered parking lots, and in City-owned parking facilities that the Director of Transportation reserves for parking vehicles used in a car-sharing program approved by the Director.

section.heading: Passenger, freight, valet parking, and mobile vending zones.
section.text: Within a passenger loading zone, freight loading zone, valet parking zone, or mobile vending zone during its operational hours.

section.heading: Bus lanes and bus stops.
section.text: Within any bus lane or bus stop designated by the Director pursuant to § 23-3 {"Designation of lanes and stops"} of this article.

section.heading: Bike lanes.
section.text: Within any bike lane designated by the Director pursuant to § 20-3 {"Designation of bike lanes"} of this article.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this subtitle, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Enabling Law.
para.text: "Enabling Law" means:
for school zone speed monitoring systems, State Code Transportation Article § 21-809; and
for work zone speed control systems, State Code Transportation Article § 21-810.

para.heading: Speed monitoring or control system.
para.text: "Speed monitoring or control system" means, except as otherwise specified, either or both:
a school zone speed monitoring system established under State Code Transportation Article § 21-809; and
a work zone speed control system established under State Code Transportation Article § 21-810.

section.heading: Systems authorized.
section.text: The use and enforcement of speed monitoring or control systems in Baltimore City is authorized.

section.heading: Governing standards, etc.
section.text: Neither a school zone speed monitoring system nor a work zone speed control system may be used except in accordance with and subject to the standards, procedures, requirements, limitations, and other provisions of:

para.text: the State Enabling Law applicable to that system; and
this subtitle and the rules and regulations adopted under this subtitle.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: A violation recorded by a speed monitoring or control system may be enforced as provided in the State Enabling Law for that system.

para.heading: Newly moved or placed school zone system.

para.text: This subsection applies only to school zone speed monitoring systems established under State Code Transportation Article § 21-809.

If a school zone speed monitoring system is moved to or placed at a location where a school zone speed monitoring system had not previously been moved to or placed at, a citation for a violation recorded by that system may not be issued:
until signage is installed in accordance with the State Enabling Law; and
for at least the first 15 calendar days after the signage is installed.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The Department of Transportation and the Police Department may jointly develop and adopt rules and regulations to govern the implementation and use of speed monitoring or control systems.

para.heading: Coverage.
para.text: These rules and regulations may, among other things, establish procedures and standards for:
the procurement of system devices;
the employment or procurement of system operators;
the placement and operation of system devices.

para.heading: To be compliant with Enabling Law.
para.text: All rules and regulations adopted under this section must be compliant with the applicable State Enabling Law.

para.heading: Filing with Legislative Reference.
para.text: A copy of all rules and regulations adopted under this subtitle must be filed with the Department of Legislative Reference before they take effect.

annotations.annotation: This subtitle was enacted by Ordinance 13-158, effective October 1, 2012.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this subtitle, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Commercial vehicle monitoring system.
para.text: "Commercial vehicle monitoring system" means a monitoring system authorized by the Enabling Law to enforce local restrictions on the presence of certain vehicles in certain places during certain times.

para.heading: Enabling Law.
para.text: "Enabling Law" means State Transportation Article § 24-111.3.

section.heading: Use of system authorized.
section.text: The use of a commercial vehicle monitoring system is authorized in Baltimore City to enforce restrictions on the presence of certain vehicles in certain places during certain times.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: A commercial vehicle monitoring system may not be used except in accordance with and subject to the prerequisites, standards, procedures, requirements, limitations, and other provisions of:
the State Enabling Law; and
this subtitle and the rules and regulations adopted under this subtitle.

para.heading: Maximum number of operational cameras.
para.text: No more than 16 cameras may be operational at any one time.

section.heading: Enforcement.
section.text: A violation recorded by a commercial vehicle monitoring system is enforceable as provided in the State Enabling Law.

section.heading: Fine proceeds.
section.text: The fines that the City collects through a commercial vehicle monitoring system may be expended by the City only for the purposes specified in the State Enabling Law.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The Department of Transportation and the Police Department may jointly develop and adopt rules and regulations to govern the implementation and use of a commercial vehicle monitoring system.

para.heading: Coverage.
para.text: These rules and regulations may, among other things, establish procedures and standards for:
the procurement of system devices;
the employment or procurement of system operators; and
the placement and operation of system devices.

para.heading: To be compliant with Enabling Law.
para.text: All rules and regulations adopted under this subtitle must be compliant with the State Enabling Law.
All rules and regulations proposed under this subtitle must be published for public comment on the website of the Department of Transportation for at least 30 days.
After this comment period, the Department of Transportation and the Police Department may modify the proposed rules and regulations and adopt final rules and regulations.

para.heading: Filing with Legislative Reference.
para.text: A copy of all rules and regulations adopted under this subtitle must be filed with the Department of Legislative Reference before they take effect.

container.heading: Parking, etc., Fines, Penalties, and Procedures

section.heading: In general.
section.text: In addition to the costs stipulated in the Maryland Code, the following fines are imposed for violation of the offenses indicated.

para.text: Parking or standing a commercial vehicle with a maximum gross vehicle weight of more than 20,000 pounds in violation of § 6-26(b) {"Stopping by residence"} or of § 6-26(c) {"Nighttime hours"} of this article is punishable by a fine of $500.

Stopping or parking in a space reserved for disabled persons or helpers under § 6-9 {"Disabled persons"} or Subtitle 9 {"Disabled Persons and Helpers"} of this article is punishable by a fine of $500.
Parking, stopping, or standing in violation of § 6-18 {"[U]nlawful dumping"} or § 6-19 {"[Waste hauler] without license displayed"} of this article is punishable by a fine of $500.
Parking or standing a vendor truck in violation of § 6-28 {"Vendor trucks"} of this article is punishable by a fine of $500.

annotation.doc: City of Balt., Md., cf. Ord. 03-591

para.text: Abandoning a vehicle in violation of § 31-8 {"Abandoned vehicles"}of this article is punishable by a fine of $300.
Parking an unidentifiable vehicle in violation of § 31-12 {"Unidentifiable vehicles"}of this article is punishable by a fine of $300.

Parking or standing a noncommercial vehicle of more than 20,000 pounds gross weight or a commercial vehicle of 20,000 pounds or less gross vehicle weight in violation of § 6-26(b) {"Stopping by residence"} of this article is punishable by a fine of $250.
Obstructing or impeding the free flow of traffic by a commercial vehicle is punishable by a fine of $250.

Parking, stopping, or standing in a manner that obstructs or impedes the free flow of vehicular or pedestrian traffic along a block face abutting or immediately across the street from the grounds of a building used as a public or private kindergarten, elementary school, or secondary school, on any school day between the hours of 7 a.m and 9 a.m. or between the hours of 2 p.m. and 5 p.m., is punishable by a fine of $250.

Parking or standing a camping trailer, mobile home, motor home, or travel trailer in violation of § 6-29(b) {"Camping trailers, mobile homes, motor homes and travel trailers: Stopping by residence"} of this article is punishable by a fine of $250.
Parking or standing in a bus lane or a bus stop in violation of § 23-5 {"Parking restrictions"} of this article is punishable by a fine of $250.
Parking or standing in a bike lane in violation of § 20-5 {"Parking restrictions"} of this article is punishable by a fine of $250.

annotation.doc: City of Balt., Md., cf. Ord. 03-591

section.heading: $125 fines.
section.text: Obstructing or impeding the free flow of traffic within an intersection or a marked crosswalk is punishable by a fine of $125.

para.text: Parking, stopping, or standing in violation of posted restrictions for the Pimlico Race Track Area is punishable by a fine of $100.

Parking, stopping, or standing in violation of posted restrictions in any Residential Permit Parking Program Area within the Camden Yards Stadium Complex Area, at any time between 1 hour before the advertised start of a stadium event and 1 hour after the event ends, is punishable by a fine of $100.

Parking, stopping, or standing in a manner that obstructs or impedes the free flow of vehicular or pedestrian traffic is punishable by a fine of $100, subject to the requirements of subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph (3).
Except as provided in sub-subparagraph (B) of this subparagraph (ii), the Transportation Department may not issue a citation for this offense unless:
it first issues a written warning, ordering the obstruction or impediment to be removed within 15 minutes of the warning; and
the obstruction or impediment is not removed within the specified time.

This subparagraph (ii) does not apply, and a citation may be issued without a prior warning, on a street marked as a snow emergency route at any time between the hours of 7 a.m and 9:30 a.m. or between the hours of 4 p.m. and 6 p.m.
This paragraph (3) does not apply to an obstruction or impediment:
by a commercial vehicle, as provided in § 36-4(2) of this subtitle;
along a block face abutting or across from the grounds of a school, as provided in § 36-4(3) of this subtitle; or
within an intersection or a marked crosswalk, as provided in § 36-4.1 of this subtitle.
Parking on a Snow Emergency Route in violation of § 6-15 {"Snow emergency routes"} of this article is punishable by a fine of $75.
Obstructing or impeding the movement of pedestrians is punishable by a fine of $75.
Standing within 15 feet of a fire plug or fire hydrant in violation of § 6-6(a) {"Fire hydrants"} of this article is punishable by a fine of $75.
Stopping in front of or opposite a fire engine house in violation of § 6-6(c) {"Engine houses"} of this article is punishable by a fine of $75.
Stopping or parking in a transit stop is punishable by a fine of $75.

Parking or standing a noncommercial vehicle of more than 20,000 pounds gross weight or a commercial vehicle of 20,000 pounds or less gross weight in violation of § 6-26(c) {"Nighttime hours"} of this article is punishable by a fine of $75.

para.text: Parking, stopping, or standing where parking, stopping, or standing is prohibited and impounding is authorized is punishable by a fine of $50.
A parking meter violation on an impounding street during the hours that a vehicle may be impounded is punishable by a fine of $50.
Parking or standing at the entrance of a public parking lot or garage in violation of § 6-8 {"Entrances to ... lots or garages"} of this article is punishable by a fine of $30.
Obstructing a driveway in violation of § 6-12 {"Private driveways"} of this article is punishable by a fine of $30.
A parking meter violation during the hours that parking at the meter is permitted is punishable by a fine of $30.
Any parking, standing, or stopping violation of this article not otherwise provided for in this subtitle is punishable by a fine of $30.

section.heading: Residential Permit Parking violations – Progressive fines.
section.text: Except as otherwise provided in this subtitle for the Pimlico Race Track Area or the Camden Yards Stadium Complex Area, parking in violation of posted permit parking restrictions in a Residential Permit Parking Program Area is punishable by the following fines:

para.text: 1st violation – $50.
2nd violation within a 12-month period – $70.
3rd violation within a 12-month period – $100.
4th and any subsequent violation within a 12-month period – $150.

para.heading: Payment to Director of Finance.
para.text: All fines imposed by this subtitle shall be payable to the Director of Finance, who shall control the issuance of prenumbered citation forms to the Police Department and record the final disposition of each citation.

para.heading: Notice to Court.
para.text: Upon receipt of notification that the recipient of a citation intends to stand trial for said offense, the Director of Finance shall forward to the District Court a copy of the citation and a copy of the notice from the person who received the citation indicating his intention to stand trial.

para.heading: Notice to offender.
para.text: If a person fails to pay the appropriate fine for a violation by the date specified in the citation and fails to file a notice of intention to stand trial for the offense, a formal notice of the violation shall be sent to the owner's last known address.
If, within 15 days from the date of the notice, the citation has not been satisfied, the person who received the citation is liable for a penalty equal to the lesser of:
$16 for each month or part of a month the citation remains unsatisfied; and
10 times the amount of the fine imposed for the violation for which the citation was issued.

If the person who received the citation agrees to a payment schedule acceptable to the Director of Finance or, if the matter has been referred to a collection agency, acceptable to that agency, the monthly penalty imposed under paragraph (1) of this subsection does not accrue while the person is making timely payments in accord with the agreed-to schedule.

If the City has requested the State Motor Vehicle Administration to refuse registration or transfer of registration of the subject vehicle until the charge has been satisfied, a further penalty of $25 is imposed.
These penalties are in addition to and may be collected in the same manner as the fines imposed by this subtitle.

para.heading: General authority to offer amnesty.
para.text: Except as otherwise provide in this section, the Director of Finance, with the approval of the Board of Estimates, may periodically offer amnesty from the payment of penalties that have accumulated on fines for parking, stopping, or standing violations.

Within 60 days of the enactment of this section, the Director of Finance shall offer a 2-day amnesty period during which outstanding fines for parking, stopping, and standing violations may be paid without liability for any penalties that have accumulated on those fines.
At the end of that 2-day amnesty period, no further amnesties may be offered for 10 years.

para.heading: Rules and regulations.
para.text: Subject to Title 4 {"Administrative Procedure Act – Regulations"} of the City General Provisions Article, the Director of Finance may adopt rules and regulations to carry out this section.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In addition to the powers granted to the Director of Finance in connection with the collection of the fines and penalties imposed by this subtitle, the Director may:
subject to Title 4 {"Administrative Procedure Act – Regulations"} of the City General Provisions Article, adopt rules and regulations as the Director considers necessary or proper:
to fully collect the fines and penalties imposed by this subtitle; and
to define any terms used in connection with the collection of those fines and penalties;
waive all fines, penalties, charges, and costs where there has been a material error in the preparation of the citation;

delegate any of his or her powers, duties, or functions in connection with the collection of the fines, penalties, charges, and costs imposed by this subtitle and the enforcement of the provisions relating to them to any other agent, representative, or employee of the Director or the City;
refund the amount of any charge paid in error, within 3 years from the date of the erroneous payment; and
refund or waive collateral, towing charges, and storage costs that, in the Director's opinion and in accordance with the Director's regulations, have been improperly assessed.

para.heading: Reporting certain actions.
para.text: Any action taken under subsection (a)(4) or (5) of this section must be documented in a monthly report prepared by the Director and submitted to the City Auditor for review.

section.heading: General fine.
section.text: Any person violating any provision or regulation of this article shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be fined a sum not exceeding $100 for each and every offense, except where another penalty is specified.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this subtitle, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Dockless vehicle.
para.text: "Dockless vehicle" means a bicycle, e-bike, e-scooter, or any other vehicle type approved by the Director and not otherwise defined in this subtitle that does not require the construction of a special docking location for its use.

para.heading: Dockless vehicle for hire.
para.text: "Dockless vehicle for hire" means a dockless vehicle available for short-term rental by a provider for the purpose of providing individual transportation on a public right-of-way.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: "E-bike" means a device designed and equipped with:
an electric motor for self-propulsion;
2 tandem wheels, either of which is more than 20 inches in diameter; and
a locking device to either lock itself or lock to existing structures.

para.heading: Exclusions.
para.text: "E-bike" does not include:
a motorcycle;
a motor vehicle;
a public transportation vehicle;
a dirt bike as defined in Article 19, § 40-1(c) {"Definitions – Dirt bike"}; or
a minibike as defined in Article 19, § 40-1(d) {"Definitions – Minibike"}.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: "E-scooter" means a device designed and equipped with:
an electric motor for self-propulsion;
2 wheels below a platform on which a user can stand upright to operate and control the vehicle; and
a locking device to either lock itself or lock to existing structures.

para.heading: Exclusions.
para.text: "E-scooter" does not include:
a motorcycle;
a motor vehicle;
a public transportation vehicle;
a dirt bike as defined in Article 19, § 40-1(c) {"Definitions – Dirt bike"};
a minibike as defined in Article 19, § 40-1(d) {"Definitions – Minibike"}; or
an electronic personal assisted device.

para.heading: Enforcement officer.
para.text: "Enforcement officer" has the meaning stated in City Code Article 1, § 41-1(c).

para.heading: Provider.
para.text: "Provider" means any person that provides dockless vehicles for hire.

para.heading: Program.
para.text: "Program" means the Dockless Vehicle Program established pursuant to this subtitle.

para.heading: User.
para.text: "User" means any individual who operates a dockless vehicle.

section.heading: Rules and regulations.
section.text: Subject to Title 4 {"Administrative Procedure Act – Regulations"} of the City General Provisions Article, the Director must adopt rules and regulations to carry out this subtitle.

annotations.annotation: By authority of Ordinance 20-431, Section 5, the Director of Legislative Reference, in consultation with the Law Department, has conformed this section to refer expressly to and reflect the requirements of the recently-enacted Administrative Procedure Act that, effective January 15, 2021, governs the proposal, adoption, and publication of administrative rules and regulations.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: There is a Dockless Vehicle Program established for the purpose of regulating the operation of dockless vehicles and dockless vehicles for hire.

para.heading: Department of Transportation to administer.
para.text: The Department is responsible for administering in a manner consistent with this subtitle.

para.heading: Cost recovery.
para.text: The cost of Program administration shall be charged to the providers through the imposition of fees established by the Department and approved by the Board of Estimates.
The Program may be terminated at any time by:
the Director, with 60 days prior written notice to the City Council and all providers; or
ordinance of the Mayor and City Council.
A termination of the Program operates to
revoke all existing permits issued under this subtitle; and
require all dockless vehicles for hire to be removed from public right-of-ways within 48 hours from the effective date of the termination.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The Program established by this subtitle must provide, in a manner established by the Director, equitable access to dockless vehicles for hire throughout the City and in under-served areas.

para.heading: Director to determine.
para.text: On an annual basis, the Director must determine:
the maximum and minimum number of providers to be permitted under this subtitle; and
the maximum and minimum number and types of dockless vehicles permitted to operate under this subtitle.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: No provider may operate a dockless-vehicle-for-hire business without having first obtained a permit from the Director.

para.heading: Issuance.
para.text: The Director may issue a permit under this subtitle in the form the Director requires.

para.heading: Form.
para.text: An application for a permit to operate a dockless-vehicle-for-hire business must be submitted in the form required by the rules and regulations adopted under this subtitle.

para.heading: Contents.
para.text: The permit application must include:
the provider's full legal name and any trade name(s) under which it operates;

documentary evidence from an insurance company indicating that the insurance company has bound itself to provide liability insurance to the provider as required by the Director in the rules and regulations adopted under this subtitle;
an agreement to indemnify the City;
a performance bond as provided in § 38-23 of this subtitle; and
any other information required by the rules and regulations adopted under this subtitle.

para.heading: Term.
para.text: A permit issued under this subtitle expires on the 1st anniversary of its effective date and is renewable as provided in this section.

para.heading: Renewal application.
para.text: The application for renewal must be in the form and contain the information required under § 38-9 of this subtitle.

section.heading: Permit not transferable or shareable.
section.text: A permit issued under this subtitle to any provider is not assignable or transferable to or shareable with any other provider not identified in the permit.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: As a condition to holding a permit, a provider must submit data and reports as required by the Director in a format determined by the Director.
Except as otherwise required by law, the data and reports provided to the Department under this section must be kept confidential.
If disclosure of the data and reports is required by law, the Department must provide the provider with reasonable prior notice of the disclosure.
A provider must establish a privacy policy approved by the Department that safeguards user information.

The data and reports provided to the Department under this section may not include information that can reasonably be used to contact or distinguish a person, including IP addresses or device identifiers.
The Department must report the data provided under this section on the Department's website.
The content and timing of the data reported under this subsection must be:
determined by the Director; and
compliant with all applicable laws.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: After a hearing conducted in accordance with the rules and regulations adopted under this subtitle and with proper notice to the provider, the Department may revoke a permit if the Department finds that the provider:
intentionally or knowingly made a false statement as to a material matter on the permit application;
failed to maintain the liability insurance required by the Director in the rules and regulations adopted under this subtitle;
failed to supply the data required under this subtitle or the rules and regulations adopted under this subtitle;
failed to pay any fees and taxes required under this subtitle or the Baltimore City Code; or
failed to provide a performance bond as provided in § 38-23 of this subtitle.
Any revocation under this section must be in writing from the Department and specify the reasons for the action.
A provider receiving a revocation under this section is prohibited from applying for a permit under this subtitle for 2 years from the date of the revocation.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: A provider aggrieved by a decision of the Department may appeal that decision to the Director in writing within 10 days of the Department's decision.

para.heading: Decision.
para.text: The Director must issue a written decision within 30 days of receipt of the provider's appeal.

section.heading: Data breaches.
section.text: If a provider determines that a breach of its data system has occurred and that the breach has placed user personal information at risk, the provider must, within 48 hours of that determination, notify the Department and all current and prior users of the breach and the likely consequences of the breach.

section.heading: Unlawful operations of e-bike or e-scooter.
section.text: An e-bike or e-scooter may not be operated:

para.text: in a manner that violates applicable State or local law;
at speeds that exceeds 15 miles per hour for e-scooters and 20 miles per hour for e-bikes when propelled solely by the electric motor and without manual power;
by a person younger than 16-years of age without a helmet;
with a passenger, unless the e-bike or e-scooter is designed to carry a passenger;
without the use of a headlight or headlamp after dusk, before dawn, or when the safe operation of a vehicle requires the use of headlight or headlamp;
on a public right-of-way where bicycles are also prohibited;
on a sidewalk, unless the posted speed on the abutting public right-of-way is 30 miles per hour or greater and the speed of the e-bike or e-scooter on the sidewalk does not exceed 6 miles per hour;
while carrying a package, bundle, or other article that prevents the user from keeping both hands on the handlebars; or
while physically controlling more than one dockless vehicle.

para.heading: Public streets and alleys.
para.text: A dockless vehicle may not be parked on a public street or alley unless the Director has designated an area specially-designed to accommodate dockless vehicle parking.

para.heading: Sidewalks.
para.text: Unless otherwise prohibited by law, rule, or regulation that specifically prohibits parking on a sidewalk, dockless vehicles may be parked:
on any sidewalk; or
at designated locations as determined by the Director.

para.heading: Miscellaneous locations.
para.text: A dockless vehicle may not be parked in:
a driveway without the permission of the owner of the driveway;
an area reserved for sidewalk dining;
a transit zone, including bus stops, shelters, and passenger-waiting areas, except at designated areas within a transit zone, as determined by the Director;
a loading zone;
a parking zone dedicated to accessible parking;
a manner that reduces the pedestrian zone to less than 4 feet or that otherwise prohibits the free flow of pedestrian traffic;
a manner that interferes with places of access for persons with disabilities as required by the Americans with Disabilities Act; or
a manner or location prohibited by the Director by rule or regulation.

para.heading: Manner of parking.
para.text: Dockless vehicles must be parked in a standing upright position.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: A provider must educate its users in the laws, rules, and regulations applicable to the riding, operation, and parking of dockless vehicles.

para.heading: Publication.
para.text: As a component of the education required under this section, a provider must make visible on its dockless vehicles or publish on its mobile application, or both, the standards of operation set forth in § 38-18 and § 38-19 of this subtitle or the rules and regulations adopted under this subtitle.

section.heading: Prohibited advertising.
section.text: A provider may not display third party advertising on its dockless vehicles.

section.heading: Provider operational responsibilities.
section.text: A provider must:

para.text: operate a 24-hour customer service phone number for users, the general public, and City officials to report dockless vehicles that are inoperable or suspected of being operated or parked in apparent violation of the law;
remove its dockless vehicles from any public right-of-way during the hours as determined by the Director;
ensure that its dockless vehicles are parked as required by law, rule, or regulation;
remove or reposition its dockless vehicles that are parked illegally within a time determined by the Director;
ensure that its dockless vehicles adhere to applicable national safety standards;
ensure that its operations adhere to the requirements of equitable access as determined by the Director; and
comply with all other requirements established by the Director for the operation of dockless vehicles for hire.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Providers must provide a performance bond in an amount and form specified by the Director.

para.heading: Use.
para.text: The funds available from the bond required by this section shall be applied to pay for:
damage to public property caused by a provider's dockless vehicles; or
the removal and storage of a provider's dockless vehicles that are parked illegally.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: A dockless vehicle for hire is subject to seizure if it is parked or used in violation of this subtitle.
An enforcement officer need not have a warrant in order to seize a dockless vehicle for hire in violation of this subtitle if:
the enforcement officer has probable cause to believe that the dockless vehicle for hire has been parked or used in violation of this subtitle; and
a warrant is not constitutionally required under the circumstances.
Whenever an enforcement officer seizes a dockless vehicle for hire under this section, the enforcement officer may cause it to be moved to a place designated by the Department.
On the seizure of a dockless vehicle for hire under this section, the Department must promptly notify the provider of:
the reason for seizure;
the location of the seized dockless vehicle for hire; and
the amount of the fees, if any, associated with the seizure.

para.heading: Vehicles returned on payment.
para.text: Any dockless vehicle for hire seized under this section must be returned to its provider on payment from funds provided by the performance bond required by § 38-23 of this subtitle.

para.heading: Rules and regulations.
para.text: The rules and regulations adopted under this subtitle must include the administration and processes necessary to implement this section.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In addition to any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement procedure, this subtitle may be enforced by issuance of:
an environmental citation as authorized by City Code Article 1, Subtitle 40 {"Environmental Control Board"}; or
a civil citation as authorized by City Code Article 1, Subtitle 41 {"Civil Citations"}.

para.heading: Process not exclusive.
para.text: The issuance of a citation to enforce this subtitle does not preclude pursuing any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement action authorized by law.

para.heading: Each day a separate offense.
para.text: Each day that a violation continues is separate offense.
